title: Yes Bank Stock Jumped Today, but Should Investors Cheer the Good News?
text:
Yes Bank (NS: ) was the shining star on the index with its stock jumping by 13.5% in today’s trade. So what was the trigger behind this spurt? Yes Bank’s stock jumped on the reports that the bank is looking to sell a minority stake to a global technology company to strengthen its balance sheet. However, the bank has not confirmed this report, and in the scenario, this news is proved wrong, the stock’s fall could be even more severe. Yes Bank’s investors need this good news to go through after the bank has been hampered with a spate of bad press surrounding it in the last year or so.

Yes Bank’s troubles began last year when RBI alleged Yes Bank of corporate governance issues and poor compliance culture prevailing at that time. RBI also recommended to the Yes Bank’s board to not hike bonus and remuneration of MD and CEO Rana Kapoor. It even advocated clawing back the bonus paid to him for the financial year 2015 and 2016. Then in September last year, RBI asked the bank to end Kapoor’s tenure by January 2019 and disapproved bank’s plea to extend Kapoor’s tenure.

The RBI removed Rana Kapoor for not showing enough transparency with regards to stressed loans. Kapoor’s replacement Ravneet Gill promised to resurrect the declining fortunes of the bank, but he too was faced with a mounting challenge to clean up the books of Yes Bank. A few months back, RBI censured Yes Bank of regulatory action as it pointed that the bank is deliberately trying to mislead the public by mentioning only the positive developments while other lapses and breaches are not disclosed.

Then last month, Gautam Thapar promoted CG Power and Industrial Solutions Ltd (NS: ) disclosed certain suspect transactions to the stock exchange after the audit committee of the company found out those discrepancies. Yes Bank incidentally owned a 13% stake in CG Power, which is why its stock also suffered last month.

All in all the stock has suffered from a steep decline from Rs. 320 levels to Rs. 71 in the span of one year, thereby losing 80% of its value in the process.
